comment: Nothing makes you feel heroic quite like hiding in a corner from bats! Tabletop RPGs became their own unique thing, and Computer/Video RPGs also turned into something else. I guess this is a roguelike, but one trapped in the 70s, players having to read hundreds of pages of documents, while the rest of the genre does this better and faster. I think that's what most shocked me, that there's hardly any interaction between characters, yet you're forced to play at the same time...... huh I guess that's most of the hobby now, nevermind.

This was the first game I ever mail ordered or pre-ordered (in 1978). I love AH games and Fantasy games as well; but this game (in its first edition) was enough to put me off preordering anything for DECADES.

I have read fans have fixed the "rules issues" from the first edition (now at v3 I think), but that will never get me the lost MONTHS of my (now long gone youth) of attempting (and failing) to make the game work... I remember being stunned that my beloved Avalon Hill would release a game in such an un-playable state.

Apparently the "fans" remade the game, or there are several errata...
We never even got to meet each other when playing the game with 4 players.

Goodwill find. Sold. Loved the map tiles (from Karim's redesign )... Maybe I'll print up a set and use them for a generic overland dungeon crawler. Yeah. Still, I'd love to find another copy, someday. I'll let you know.

This game is awful. The only reason I played is one of friends liked it. Conceptually, it was ambitious for 1979, but it shipped with rules that were fundamentally broken. For years, there has been errata created by fans of the game that make the game unbroken. I would not say it is playable. If you are going to play, you need to play with Realmspeak, but it is painfully long, fiddly and really pretty difficult. The game has so many exceptions, magic is incredibly complicated and even with updated rules makes little sense. Having said all this, when you beat a monster after defeating the puzzle, the game has its moments. But it is just not worth it for the amount of time it takes you to learn. Play Mage Knight if you want to play a good game that provides effectively the same experience.

You have to see this as what it is.. a piece of game history.
Would i play it for fun? No, never.
Am i facinated by it as a predecessor to modern gaming & early computer adventures? Yes, definately!

Except for the deck-building it shares many similiarities with Mage Knight by Vlaada Chvatil. But they went for a much broader & open sand-box style. That sand-box attempt comes with a rule book of 120 pages and a second highest complexity rating by it's publisher Avalon Hill.

I highly recommend trying it out, in the same way you should play a sierra adventura on the computer to see the base structure behind all dem new & shiny titles.

Spent weeks mastering this ruleset and wanted to love it so much. But at the end of the day, it's just not a well designed game. The forums for the game are full of fans who swear by the 'depth' that comes from learning characters, counting your odds, etc. Honestly don't believe it. I respectfully believe these players are seeing the game theough very rosy nostalgic glasses. There is *not* depth to your decisions in the modern definition of the word. It's a game full of walls that provides no toolkit to climb them. There's no skill set to develop as a player, and no decisions to ponder beyond the chances behind your next die roll. Success in this game is rolling a die to loot treasure as your sole action for 10 or more full turns in a row (in a 30 turn game), and hoping maybe you roll the number that unlocks a path to progress on. Using detailed game knowledge (card distributions, etc.) from repeated plays to slightly increase your winrate is the only thing provided to players to compensate for the complete lack of strategy and tactics, and learning to abuse this game knowledge is the opposite of rewarding. It's depressing.

The theme and aesthetics are SO FUN and the game systems are fascinating and novel, but the game as a whole is absolutely a failed experiment.

We didn't play where you had to plan your move in advance, but I can't see that making the game better, only harder.
We didn't even do much in the way of Magic, but just the combat system itself seemed way more complicated than it should be.
I'm not really interested in playing this one again, although I do respect the game and I understand the value it has for others. I'd be willing to try this again but only solo, and I can even expect it would be fun.

Update: Years later and now I'm VERY interested in learning this game and exploring it in depth. I am confident my first play was spoiled by too many new players (me included!). I felt like I should have been the perfect target for this game. I enjoy AH games, play complex wargames like Squad Leader, and am an old school roleplayer. I also love dungeon crawls, but wanted something meatier and with more chrome than the typical dice roller. The original game rules (even second edition) are difficult to understand, but the excellent tutorial overcomes all these faults. The game is also very fiddly and has lots of chrome, but I typically do not mind this if it adds more depth and theme to a game.

My problem with Magic Realm is that it simply was not that much fun or exciting. While there are many different character classes and their special abilities and varying chits drive one to use different tactics, I just could not get very enthused about them nor did I find that I wanted to explore them more after a game. So one guy has more move chits or some T and H chits – yawn. I just could not get excited even if they had a T1 chit. Combat is complex, but it felt more like a puzzle where you tried to figure out what chit to play where and hope the denizen did not move or change tactics rather than the tactical challenge I usually find in wargames. The monsters are humdrum (does anyone really get excited about bats or wolves?) and their only real difference is their size, speed, and damage class, but other than that there was not much difference between a bat and a dragon. While the spells and treasures had some interesting names, the rest of them felt more like raw numbers with little theme. As for the adventures, there wasn’t really any mysterious temples or scary dungeons to explore. You mostly just wondered around until a chit or monster roll caused a monster to appear or you ran into another character. Yes the howls, flutters, and dank chits added a little sensory cues to the game, but not enough to overcome the other blandness.

Magic Realm is an amazing, one of a kind, fantasy classic that could only have been created at its seminal moment in time when the foundations of RPG and fantasy board gaming were being laid. Today’s game designs are focused on lowering the barrier to entry for players, and the current aesthetic calls for simplification to facilitate play. In the era of Magic Realm’s creation the accepted paradigm was, “the more effort you put into a game, the more enjoyment you could take from it.” The extensive rules provided fuel for players’ imagination.

Magic Realm is an artifact from the past, but one that can still provide great pleasure if approached with an awareness of its origins.

This really is the ultimate fantasy game. The sheer number of options that you have to consider in any given game is dwarfed only by the sheer number of rules and exceptions that need to be learned. However, the combat system is amazing, adding brutal realism but clever tactics to what is often replaced with a single die roll in other fantasy games. The exploration and prowling rolls make for the most exciting map in any exploration game. The die roll system is brutal but productive. The magic system has so many nuances and strategies that it's virtually a different game.

I can say so many things about this game, but really, only playing it can live up to your expectations and curiosity.

As to what edition to get, I have the Avalon Hill edition. I have examined the Karim redesign very closely. There are advantages to both. The AH design has generally better art and strictly better map tiles. However, weapon chits, monster chits, and denizen chits all leave something to be desired. Also, AH magic cards and treasure cards are functionally fine and terrible material-wise. Karim's redesign fixes many of the problems with the chits, adding a significant amount of information to the chits themselves and, more importantly, adding a consistent visual organization to the graphical design of the chits. I can't understate how nice this is. I'm very tempted to just make parts of the Karim redesign to mix with parts of the AH copy I have.

Jay Richardson's tutorial has been overwhelmingly useful. Go download it from the files section if you have not yet done so. 3rd edition rules are also necessary, and can be found in the same place.

I hardly even know how to talk about it. Right now I'm mostly just in awe that this thing even exists. There are ideas here that I haven't seen anywhere else, and despite the ridiculous complexity it all somehow makes sense.

Games are more than entertainment. If you want to see what it looks like when someone pushes the form to its absolute limits, you owe it to yourself to try Magic Realm out. Check out the BGG forums to download Realmspeak and start working through the Book of Learning. If there's anything quite like this, I haven't found it.
